Here's how I dug this out, I didn't think this would work because of the resource fuckery, but it totally does:
1. Build the same version of Electron locally, in Release mode with the same arch
2. Open the crash dump in WinDbg
3. Type this in (don't type in the C++-style comments)

```
.symfix
.symopt+ 0x40   // SYMOPT_LOAD_ANYTHING, ignore the fact that speak.exe doesn't match our built version
.sympath+ C:\Path\to\electron\out\R
!analyze -v
```
Does it happen on startup or after doing some operation? And will it help if you put `require('web-contents')` in the beginning of your main script?

I'm not sure because it's happening in prod and I've never seen this myself (we get 5-10 of these reports/day at the minute though). I could certainly try adding the require into our next release and see if it prevents the issue but it might be a week or so before we'd know for sure...

@zcbenz I tried putting `require('web-contents')` in there in the latest production release and this is still coming in :cry: . It's definitely something to do with the app starting up or a window starting up.

This also upgraded Electron to `0.34.0`

@tommoor does it happen only on Windows 8 or also on Windows 8.1? If someone is using Windows 8, it means they haven't updated their PC in ages. It could be that whatever causes the bug is solved by a Windows update. In any case, if it happens so frequently, I think you should try to reconstruct the issue with the same exact Windows version (you can get Windows 8 VM for free from https://dev.modern.ie/tools/vms/windows/).

I checked out the latest crash reports, here's the spread:

```
Windows 7 Version 7601 (Service Pack 1)
Windows 7 Version 7601 (Service Pack 1)
Windows 7 Version 7601
Windows 7 Version 7601
Windows 8 Version 9600
Windows 8 Version 9600
Windows 8 Version 9600
Windows 8 Version 10240
Windows 8 Version 10240
Windows 8 Version 10240
Windows 8 Version 10240
Windows 8 Version 10240
```

I believe Windows 8 Version 9600 and above are SP1. I've not seen a report on Windows 10 yet.
So it's probably not a missing Windows update. You're best bet is to try and reproduce it.
